adjectives.description: underwater (comparative more underwater, superlative most underwater)

entries.meaning: (not comparable) Beneath the surface of the water; of or pertaining to the region beneath the water surface.
examples: He was a pioneer in underwater exploration.

entries.meaning: (nautical) Beneath the water line of a vessel.
examples: When the ship was brought into dry dock, it was found that she had underwater damage.

entries.meaning: (finance) Having negative equity; owing more on an asset than its market value.
examples: We've been underwater on our mortgage ever since the housing crash.

entries.meaning: (finance) Of an option, having a strike price higher (call options) or lower (put options) than the current market price of the underlying asset or financial product; for example, an option to buy shares at $20 when the current market price is $15.

adverbs.description: underwater (comparative more underwater, superlative most underwater)

entries.meaning: So as to go beneath the surface of the water.
Underlying water or body of water, for example in an aquifer or the deep ocean.
(fishing) A type of lure which lies beneath the water surface.

verbs.description: underwater (third-person singular simple present underwaters, present participle underwatering, simple past and past participle underwatered)

entries.meaning: (agriculture, horticulture) To water or irrigate insufficiently.
examples: Care must be taken not to underwater houseplants in the summer.
